Aside from an opening few minutes in the jungles of the Congo in which an expedition looking for diamonds gets wiped out by some strange gorilla-like creatures, this movie really has very little in it that would appeal. It revolves around basically three themes - the scientist who goes to the jungle looking for her former fiancé, the primatologist who wants to return a talking gorilla to her native land and a treasure- hunter who's looking for King Solomon's lost city of diamonds. The three somehow manage to team up to support each other, and we spend significant time watching them traipse through the jungles, with precious little excitement or action taking place. Amy (the talking gorilla) is kind of cute, but I found it hard to believe that this obviously domesticated gorilla would be able to survive in the wild. Still, her story may be the only one of the three that has any appeal as you wonder whether - when the inevitable moment comes when she encounters wild gorilla - she'll choose her own species or the human she's come to love. Yeah. It's kind of a bizarre love story. The "gorilla-creatures" from the movie's beginning don't re-appear until the movie's last half hour or so, which means that there's essentially a lot - and I mean A LOT - of filler.

The movie features some nice sceneries, but an unfortunately second-rate cast that seems to put enough effort into this but never really thoroughly convinces. Ernie Hudson is probably the most familiar face, supported by the likes of Laura Linney and Dylan Walsh and Joe Don Baker, who all work often enough but have never really achieved mega- stardom. There's a minor role for Joe Pantoliano, who I recognized from "The Sopranos."

Unless you really have nothing else to do, this isn't worth the effort of watching. (3/10)

review_title: Reading the book made the movie more palatable.
review_detailed_main:
All the characters were either unlikeable or irritating, except for maybe the monkey, and even her synthesized voice got to be irritating.

Still, it's a watchable movie, having watched it three times over the years.

I'll never know if reading the book first affected my opinion of the movie for better or worse. I'd have to erase my mind and watch the movie first to prove that.

Edit: Actually, when I was watching the movie for the first time, I kept thinking that the movie seemed somewhat familiar. Then it occurred to me that I had read a book titled Congo and never made the connection until the end of the movie. So I'm either not very observant or the movie had very little similarity to the book.

review_title: King Solomon's Mines meets King Kong.A good idea at the time?
Unrealistic apes but still a good movie despite this
review_detailed_main:
Despite the apes glaringly obviously humans in costumes it's an action packed family movie.

A great watch for enthusiastic viewers who enjoy escapist flicks with a decent plot line.

I recommend if you like adventure n apes in the wild lol.

I really find this movie entertaining and perhaps unintentionally humerous. Too bad it's based on a fairly good Michael Crichton novel, so must suffer in the comparison. Laura Linney is luminous as always and Ernie Hudson's take on the adventurer and expedition leader is pretty sophisticated. Tim Curry's character of the shady Hungarian seems to have been made up for the movie, as it's not in the novel. A lot of the movie is hack script writing, and filled with terrible movie tropes about the Congo, but somehow still manages to entertain. I would have loved to have seen the version with Sean Connery that Crichton wanted to make. In any case, it's worth kicking back with a bucket of popcorn and diving into this adventure.

Congo is a very quite bad movie, though I guess it's a little more entertaining than most. Where else can you see a boat get attacked by ravenous hippos? (Prompting the MST3K comment "Hungry Hungry Hippos!" from one of my friends :) And Tim Curry's accent as Herkermer Homolka is almost, but not quite as bad as Jon Voight's in Anaconda. The definite highlight of the movie, though, comes in the end where the monkeys all get killed in grisly ways. Some of them even dive into the hot lava for no reason at all. I just wish that annoying 'good' monkey would follow suit. She's incredibly annoying.

review_title: This movie makes me want to cry
review_detailed_main: The book, while not particularly great, was decent, but this movie completely changes it. A lot of the elements of the story are consistent between the book and the movie, but Dr. Ross' character goes from a creatively written character who lives for money and ends up causing the volcanic eruption with her greed to a heart-on-her-sleeve damsel in distress who won't do anything if she even catches the slightest hint that it might be less than noble. When movies change the book that much but keep the same name, it should be a crime.

This was pretty hyped from Jurassic Park, and was ripped by critics. I didn't think it was all that bad. Ernie Hudson stole the show as Monroe. As far as the rest of the characters, I could not get into them. Amy, the ape, was propably my second favorite character. The story itself was good, which saved the movie.

CONGO is probably the worst big-budget movie of the 1990s. It is so bad that it is watchable over and over again. A bunch of folks with different agendas probe deep into darkest Africa, where they encounter a temple of riches just like in KING SOLOMON'S MINES -- but with cannibalistic gorillas guarding those riches. On their side, the humans have a "talking" gorilla named Amy who helps save the day at one point or another. So much for the plot. The dialogue throughout is witless, the acting almost uniformly atrocious, certainly campy (Tim Curry and Ernie Hudson are both on hand to assure the ham factor), and the special effects abysmal. Wait until you see the cannibalistic gorillas. And the lava! Oh yes, did I mention there's a volcanic eruption to top off the big finale? Laura Linney of all people is along for this bumpiest of rides. What could she have been thinking? This is right around the same time she appeared with Richard Gere and Ed Norton in PRIMAL FEAR, a movie that helped guarantee her stardom.

review_title: "Congo" introduces Laura Linney to the world.
review_detailed_main:
In the category of films like "Raiders of the Lost Ark" and its sequels, "Congo" represents a campy adventure story that should rest on its own merits; it is neither a historical account nor an anthropological study, and doesn't purport to be; it is just fun and should be viewed within that framework. Rent it and see for yourself.

The main joy for me when I saw the film during its original release in theaters was to watch Laura Linney in her first starring role. I knew then that great things were in store for her. Not to mention her having the best dimples on the planet! I am in awe of her body of work on stage, in films, and on TV; and since she just turned 41, I look forward to her continuing to grow in her craft. My most recent experience in that regard was watching her guest-starring appearances on the last 5 episodes of "Frasier", in which she stole the show from its regular cast, and gave the series a wonderfully edgy and entertaining finish. Although she is better known for her stage and film roles, her being able to go back and forth among the various actors' venues is refreshing, not to mention her ability to devour both dramatic and comedic roles with equal proficiency. Love 'ya, Laura.

review_title: Why do bad things happen to good books?
review_detailed_main: Now, it's probably just a testament to Michael Crichton's in-depth writing style that his books translate poorly to film, but this one was just pathetic. Lost World and Sphere were bad, this was painful.

review_title: Weissmuller shakes and shudders in his tomb
One of the worst movies ever
review_detailed_main: For the most parts, movies adapted from novels loose something in the translation -- not always but a lot of the time. I find Michael Crichton's novels to be extremely entertaining and thought provoking. I only hope his involvement in this travesty of a movie is his name only. It's a terrible adaptation and it's association ruins a very good book. I only wish there was something less than 1 star in the voting.

Their vehicle is destroyed. They find a lost city. The city is inhabited. (Gorillas...Atlanteans.) Crystals...diamonds. She made a bridge! Talking animal. (OK, Mole's technically human...) Bad guy tries to steal crystal/diamond. Volcano. And, on an unrelated topic, Dylan Walsh looks astoundingly like a hobbit.

review_title: I almost shot myself after watching this flick
A modern b-movie without any of the cheesy fun but all the wooden performances, flat dialogue and rubbish plot

review_detailed_main:
Or show and tell - literally. Now this has quite a few cliches attached to it and some dialog choices may not be the best. But just the cast alone is quite incredible. And I'm ot even talking about the short appearance of Ash (Bruce Campbell) of Evil Dead fame. That is a bonus for me and anyone else who loves/adores that Dude.

The story itself is predictable with gullible characters all around. But also quite violent for a mainstream movie. I could more than handle it, I am just warning potential issues some may have with the spikes in effects/violence this includes at times. This is not Monkey Shines mind you! But you have to love animals in general - at least that's what I think.

The diamond here being the McGuffin of course, but you need an excuse for an expedition, don't you? And once you are on the trip, the entertainment and tension can start.

Ddisappointing. This is a very good book, but as is the norm, does not play well on the screen. Good actors giving bad performances. Blame the director? Maybe. Definitely watchable but in the way you have background music playing while you watch YouTube vids or read the news.

Here is my personal review of the 1995 science-fiction/adventure film "Congo," directed by Frank Marshall and produced by Kathleen Kennedy, based on the novel by "Jurassic Park" author Michael Crichton.

To start this off, I'll lay down the basic plot of the movie: TraviCom is a major electronics/telecommunications company based in Houston, Texas that sends an expedition to the Congo rain forest in Africa. The expedition's goal is to search for a deposit of extremely valuable, rare diamonds that, in the hands of TraviCom, will change the telecommunications industry overnight. However, SOMETHING slaughters the entire expedition party, and that includes the son of the company CEO that TraviCom employee Karen Ross loves. At the insistence of her boss, Karen Ross links up with Peter Elliot, a California primatetologist and his female gorilla, Amy (whom Peter has taught to paint and speak sign language with the help of an electronic glove).

Once the new expedition reaches Africa, they bring on board Monroe Kelly, a "great white hunter who happens to be black" and a Romanian philanthropist named Herkemer Homolka. The expedition faces its fare share of obstacles before finally reaching its destination; the fabled lost city of Zinj, home to the same rare diamonds that the first TraviCom expedition was looking for. Unfortunately for the protagonists, the city of Zinj is home to something deadly: genetically mutated carnivorous gray gorillas, created and trained by the ancient people of Zinj to guard the valuable diamonds. Once the gray gorillas make themselves known, the explorers learn that in the African Congo, YOU ARE THE ENDANGERED SPECIES! If you love Michael Crichton or any movie that takes place in the jungle, this is the movie for you! The story is a well-translated yet slightly different telling of Crichton's story. The characters are well-defined and the acting is on a scale of 1 to 10, a 7. The late special-effects wizard Stan Winston uses amazing, realistic costumes with animatronic masks to breathe life into the signing gorilla Amy and the terrifying gray gorillas. Amy herself is a great character brought to life by both Stan Winston's robotic ape mask and the suit performer who brought out Amy's signing skills out really well. All in all, I love this movie, and everyone who gave it a negative review needs to find a better line of work! Most of "Congo" is flawless with two exceptions. One: for a suspense movie, there were only a few scenes of pure suspense and mostly action. There needed to be more scenes of suspense (such as the gray gorillas picking off people without anyone else knowing or more scenes of pure quiet that could've suddenly exploded with a scare). Also, the origin story of the gray gorillas was merely brushed over and not explained in full. There needed to be a fully-detailed explanation of the gray's origins, such as clues throughout the city that would lead up to the discovery of their origins or an autopsy scene to determine what kind of ape they really were.

Besides those two flaws, the rest of "Congo" is pure Crichton, pure adventure, and pure fun. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves Crichton and good-old-fashioned jungle adventure stories.

I really like IMDB. The user reviews are more often than not very agreeable with mine (user reviews anyhow). This is a movie that is much better than its rating. Its no Jurassic Park or Independence Day but it is a fun ride. Excellent cast & they are doing a good job playing their parts convincingly. It has a good pace, lots of action & a pretty good mystery. I liked this movie when it came out & still enjoy it today. This flick is a solid 6.5 but there's no halves so it's gotta be a seven because it's definitely not a six. My six to sevens are movies I enjoy, watch multiple times but fall short of outstanding. 8-9 are Star Wars, Jaws, ET, Jurassic Park, Saving Private Ryan, Sling Blade, Harry Potter, one Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest & a 10 is Empire Strikes Back, Episodes like GOT The Red Wedding just for reference. Give it a chance if you're looking for something to watch. Plus I love Laura Linney. I think she's as pretty as a woman can be when she lets her hair down. Those dimples just kill me.

Great unique adventure with a wonderful cast! Laura Linney and others are great. Intriguing story about a talking chimpanzee and potentially finding goodies in the Congo among other things. Unfortunate this movie hasn't been more known although it's got cliches, it's still better than a bunch of other adventure flicks. Surpassed the F-Bomb limit of 2 it was lucky to be rated PG-13.

This movie is the opposite of art, but it still works for me. I was a big fan of the Republic "action serials" that a local TV station ran on Saturday mornings along with Tarzan/Jungle Jim movies and cartoons. I still like things like Commando Cody and "The Red Skull", which is why I liked "The Rocketeer" and was disappointed that they didn't make a sequel. This movie is of the same genre, but no one involved was even slightly serious when the made it (unlike, say, "The Rocketeer"). It's based on a typically idiotic Michael Crichton novel, and the people making it had the good sense to just have fun with it. (With the exception of "The Great Train Robbery", I can't think of a single one of his books that hasn't made a truly awful movie which becomes instantly dated.) I think that this is a junky classic.

It's hard to believe that the same guy who wrote Jurassic Park, The Andromeda Strain, Time Line and Eaters of the Dead (The 13th Warrior) wrote this container of once used fetid dog food. The premise of the story is bad enough, i.e., apes who learn American Sign Language are able to vocalize through technology but moreover, they retain arcane knowledge that is revealed in their art. But, hey. It's fiction-- even if it's bad fiction. So, for what Crichton was able to do so imaginatively for Jurassic Park fell on its face in this one. OK. Who wins them all? But, then Congo the movie shows up at the theaters and I'm dumb enough to buy a ticket. Whereas the book merely stunk, the movie reeked. Laura Linney was lovely but miscast as a corporate mercenary, Dylan Walsh was completely unbelievable as the primatologist and then the usually wonderful Tim Curry was dreadful as the eccentric Homolka. And, it goes down from there. Storywise, corporate greed in the background of Central Africa's unstable, violent and often brutal politics. My advice is don't rent it and you're watching it on TV on the late show or a rainy day, see if you can find an old rerun of I Love Lucy. It'll be much more entertaining and so much better written.

review_title: Fair to good adaptation of the novel

review_detailed_main: This is just one of those movies that continually make you groan and that I wished was over. The problems are many and the good points are few. I feel the main problem with this movie is that it has what amounts to a cheesy plot and they try to make it out to be a epic movie, which a movie about super evil monkeys and smart ones that sign just is not epic, it is cheese. When you have cheese you make the movie more fun. Granted, the final scene with the monkeys and that laser was very nice to watch and more of things of that nature was needed. Instead the actors are doing such a serious job that you feel the movie just has a corny plot amid all the serious tension the movie is trying to set up. The plot revolves around a woman trying to find what happened to her missing ex-husband while also searching for some sort of legendary diamonds. She uses these two guys who trained an ape to do sign language and now wish to return her to the wild as cover to get into the country and begin the mediocre adventure of a lifetime. The only things that make this movie somewhat tolerable is Ernie Hudson's character and the laser attack at the end.

review_title: Frankly my dear I am not all that impressed.
review_detailed_main: Congo has some cute moments, but it is simply not a great moment, other than Joe Don Baker's histrionics, plugged in directly from a James Bond film or two, and Ernie Hudson's character, this was a film with no star power, which is not always a bad thing, but also a poor script and bad directing, which fails to pull it all together. Add to that Tim Curry's one dimensional performance (he is always the wimpy slug, villain under the rock kind of character.) Give the poor guy a hero role for once so he can really surprise the audience. The character of AMy was about the best acting in the film, and you have to give good marks for the scenery and the sound score. All in all, though, it could have been better, perhaps with a few actors with more name recognition.

Congo is a silly safari adventure. Almost King Solomon Mines meets Jurassic Park (with wild apes and gorillas instead of dinosaurs.) Based on a Michael Crichton novel, this was made when Crichton was hot property back in the 1990s.

Director Frank Marshall better known as a producer for Steven Spielberg movies was not a strong enough director to make a serious adventure film opting accidentally for camp and cheese.

When an expedition to discover rare diamonds in the Congo go missing. A scientist is sent in to find out what happened especially as one of the missing men was her fiancé. She joins a crew that consists of a primatologist who is taking a trained talking gorilla back to the wild and a Romanian treasure hunter trying to locate the lost city of Zinj.

When they arrive they meet their expert guide but are captured by a local militia leader and have to bribe themselves out of trouble.

The guide tells the group that other expeditions to find the 'Lost City of Zinj' have ended in disaster.

Laura Linney and Dylan Walsh are bland in the lead roles, out-acted by the talking gorilla.

It is left to Tim Curry to ham it up as the Romanian Herkermer Homolka and Ernie Hudson in the great white African adventurer role, Captain Munro Kelly who happens to be black with an English accent. He steals the show in an otherwise bad movie.

Moon river, Lucy Liu and diamonds're forever. I still remember the punch line one of the main characters in this movie when he said that The Hidden Temple of King Solomon had never existed, so he had to buy diamonds in Tiffany like everybody else. Tim Curry, vampire Clown from Steven King's most popular book is so scary even without make up like in movie It (1990th ). In this movie he plays Romanian explorer who thinks that The Hidden Temple is full of diamonds which protect killer monkeys.

review_title: What a waste of money and talent !
review_detailed_main: I just watched Congo on DVD.In most cases I love these kind of movies but this one is different. It made me write my first comment for a movie on IMDb. I was amazed how such a team of experienced filmmakers could come up with this movie as a result. You can see there was a lot of money for this production but you can't make a good movie if you don't have a good script. And as a producer Frank Marshall gave us plenty of great movies to watch; he never should have tried to become another Spielberg. This one shows how hard it is to make a good movie, maybe you've got all the ingredients but if you can't cook stay out of the kitchen. If Can make a suggestion don't spend your money on this one. If you want to see it watch it on television first and make up your own mind.

Given the amount of technological aspects of the authors works, its hard to adapt a movie perfectly. Although I saw the movie for the first time when I was about 10 and fell in love with it. Later when I was in college I decided to read the book. First of all I was pleased and displeased with the movies accuracy. The movie tells the story and the story alone. The details of the movie can never be told except in the book. Basically the story is a guy wants a diamond, someone goes after it, but the real story is in the book. I've read many of the authors works. and the films can never convey what he really meant, Although I think this movie was a better adaptation than say Jurassic Park. The story was kept as accurate as possible given the time the movie was limited. MANY elements were omitted, and side plots were almost non-existent,such as the almost complete involvement in achieving the diamond before rival companies, but in the respect of movie goers who have never read the book, it can provide entertainment and all is well. I personally loved this movie, it was a great achievement and I hope people will enjoy the story.

review_title: Why is this movie so underrated?

Why can't movie fans rate a truly great movie like this one and rather prefer Mortal Kombat created in the same year consisting of a completely worse technical side? I'll start from the beginning.

First of all, this movie is one of my favorites without any doubt. Similarly like Jurassic Park, even Congo means my childhood to me with amazing experiences spending with this movie.

Honestly, Congo is not for everyone, it contains a lot of brutality, scary moments, sometimes there are comedy elements or just steps of adventure. Besides, I have never understood why people do not like this one, although it has everything that a good movie must have. It is full of perfect CGI, which honestly in that time of creation looked better than comparable with nowadays Jurassic world or other kinds of those movies. Great soundtrack Spirits of Africa by Jerry Goldsmith who's known from Rambo. Actors were pleasant. Ernie Hudson played James Bond in the jungle, Dylan Wallsh a young scientist, who learns gorillas talk with help of modern technology of science, Laura Linney fiancee of Bruce Campbell and Tim Curry as Homolka longing for gold, then what's wrong with Congo? As I mentioned, the plot deserves praise. We have an impressive story about the relationship among a human and a gorilla, however at least this fact was supposed to be rated. To be honest, nothing is wrong with Congo and the filmmakers have done a great job.

I did not find any mistakes I would have to say any bad words for. Maybe if the critics want, the weakest part of Congo belongs to Laura Linney, I would have supposed someone else instead of her, she's not a good actress, but it's too small a problem in order to decrease my ranking.

review_detailed_main: I find the two names Helkemer Homolka and Heinrich Himmler rhyming, even in some cases the mannerism, mental state and don't care attitude to people lives-that is when i watch the movie and read about Himmler. When you read History of Third Reich and the second world war: when Himmler's arrest and conviction was imminent for crimes he was party to, too well-he still thought he could negotiate and become the post war German minister of police! Mr Homolka could see death in his eyes but could not let go of his diamonds! review_title: People realize this is based off of a book, right?
review_detailed_main: Based on a lot of the really high reviews, I'm guessing they don't realize the film is based off of a book. Saying "the story line is pretty decent". The book is great. The movie as a stand alone is pretty decent, a lot of the movie seems really rushed and trying to wrap it up quickly.

"Congo" is without question the silliest adventure film I've ever seen. It's a badly made film even though it's never boring. And boy did I laugh out loud while watching this! It's incredible at how unintetionally hilarious this movie is. "Congo" is a movie so ridiculous, so stupid, so idiotic, and so dumb that I found myself cracking up during many scenes. The plot of "Congo" is about an expedition that goes into the jungles of Africa who come face-to-face with killer gorillas. Since it's a waste of my time to explain the rest of the goofy plot, I just get down to what's good and bad about "Congo". Here's the good stuff. As far as the cast goes, there are only two good performances turned in by Laura Linney as the communications expert looking for her fiance who's disappeared in the African jungle and Ernie Hudson as the group's tour guide. Plus, some of the African scenery looks beautiful with the cinematographer of "E.T." (Allen Daviau) doing the honors here. Now here's the bad stuff (and there's alot of it). The worst acting honors for "Congo" go to Tim Curry who gives one of the most laughable film performances of all-time. Curry, speaking with a bad foreign accent, plays a Romanian fortune hunter obsessed with finding a long lost city that Hudson believes does not exist. Another silly character in the film is Amy the talking gorilla, who when having a special speaking device on talks with a schoolgirl voice that's sounds absolutely ridiculous. The screenplay by John Patrick Shanley (based on Michael Crichton's novel) has alot of preposterous dialogue. And it's hard to imagine that Frank Marshall directed this. Marshall, who's first directing effort was the very good horror/comedy "Arachnophobia", is a protege of Steven Spielberg. Spielberg, Marshall, and "Congo" producer Kathleen Kennedy (Marshall's real-life wife) developed Spielberg's production company Amblin Entertainment during the '80s. Marshall as worked with Spielberg on some of the biggest box-office hits of all-time (he produced the "Indiana Jones" trilogy) and scored a huge box-office hit last year on his own as co-producer (with Kennedy) of "The Sixth Sense". But I have no idea what Marshall was thinking of when he made "Congo". It should have been a thrilling adventure tale but instead turns out to be a comedy of epic proportions. Marshall directed this as if it's a really serious movie. If it's supposed to be serious, why is it so funny? I was constantly laughing at the Tim Curry character because he's made out to be a nut; same goes for the talking gorilla. "Congo" has a couple of good things going for it, but it's just too ridiculous.

*1/2 (out of four)

review_title: Tons of Cheesy Jungle Adventure Fun
review_detailed_main:
This is one of my many guilty pleasures as far as action movies go, probably because I have a preference for jungle adventures in the vein of Tarzan; especially if there's a lost civilization involved.

The film is based on the 1980 novel by Michael Crichton, which I've read and consider superior to this. TraviCom scientist Dr. Karen Ross (Laura Linney) is sent deep into the Congo rainforest to locate her missing ex-fiancé, Charles Travis (Bruce Campbell) by his father RB Travis (Joe Don Baker), who is after a rare diamond that can revolutionize the communications business. Coincidentally, Dr. Peter Elliot (Dylan Walsh) seeks to bring his sign-language speaking mountain gorilla Amy (voice by Shayna Fox) back to Africa, joined by Romanian philanthropist, Herkermer Homolka (Tim Curry) who is after the lost city of Zinj where the diamonds are located. And so, the two parties meet up, and are led by Captain Monroe Kelly (Ernie Hudson) on a dangerous expedition to find the diamonds.

The acting ranges from stale to hilariously cheesy. Dylan Walsh was indifferent throughout the movie and has a blank expression on his face, even when he's shooting at the Zinj gorillas. It might have been better if Bruce Campbell played Dr. Elliot instead. Laura Linney is a decent action lady, but she looks puzzled at times and speaks her lines awkwardly. Amy is annoying and she soured the experience for me. It's Tim Curry and Ernie Hudson who carry the film. Curry is so over the top cheesy, you'll love every second he spends onscreen, and Hudson is great with his badass and wise-cracking Clark Gable impersonation. They're obviously fake Romanian (Curry) and British (Hudson) make them even more enjoyable. There are also a few notable cameos, like Delroy Lindo as Captain Wanta with his legendary meme "Stop eating my sesame cake!".

The filming locations ranged from California, Costa Rica, Tanzania, Kenya, and Uganda. The scenery and set designs were impressive, with Matte paintings and miniatures used for the beautifully lush Congo jungle and the city of Zinj; the collapsing ruins and emerging lava pits during the climatic volcanic eruption were the best looking of all.

The creature effects and designs weren't perfect either, despite Stan Winston being in charge. While Amy and the wild, lowland gorillas and Hippo animatronics look good for 1995, the Zinj gorillas were obviously a mixture of puppets, suits, and animatronics. To be fair, though, CGI was not yet developed enough at the time to make realistic looking gorillas, so this is excusable.

The action scenes were quite enjoyable. From the frightening, night-time hippo attack to the final battle inside the mines against the Zinj gorillas, the movie doesn't disappoint in keeping the audience hooked. The sound effects were intense and cool sounding, like gunfire and intimidating animals' noises, such as Hippo bellows, birds cooing, and the Zinj gorilla snarls.

Still, if the bad acting and dialogue is too much for you, you might want to try reading the novel instead.

Based on Michael Crichton's novel, film is about a research/rescue team sent into the African Congo, and led by Dr. Karen Ross(Laura Linney) that includes Dr. Peter Elliot(Dylan Walsh) who has with him a talking gorilla(due to a new technology in her larynx). Tim Curry and Ernie Hudson play devious characters who are also along for the mission. They are sent to locate the first research team that had apparently located some large and pure diamonds that are worth a fortune to the company funding the expeditions. Complicating matters are the instability of the local government, and a rumored mythical race of apes said to live deep in the jungle. As it turns out, they are no myth...

Lightweight adventure yarn is watchable to a point, but too silly and outlandish to succeed, though it remains innocuous.

review_title: VERY bad movie of a VERY excellent book
review_detailed_main: It is a shame that such a great book was turned into such a terrible movie. I could not wait to see this movie after reading the book....it really did not do it justice.

This is one of Crichton's best books. The characters of Karen Ross, Peter Elliot, Munro, and Amy are beautifully developed and their interactions are exciting, complex, and fast-paced throughout this impressive novel.

And about 99.8 percent of that got lost in the film. Seriously, the screenplay AND the directing were horrendous and clearly done by people who could not fathom what was good about the novel. I can't fault the actors because frankly, they never had a chance to make this turkey live up to Crichton's original work. I know good novels, especially those with a science fiction edge, are hard to bring to the screen in a way that lives up to the original. But this may be the absolute worst disparity in quality between novel and screen adaptation ever. The book is really, really good. The movie is just dreadful.
Really wish it was as good as the book. Good actors though.

review_title: Congo" is a failure of imagination
review_detailed_main:
Review of Congo (1995)

"Congo" isn't just bad-it's a catastrophic misfire that manages to insult its audience, squander its talented cast, and embarrass everyone involved. This movie is proof that even with a budget, source material by Michael Crichton, and a stellar team of actors, you can still create an irredeemable disaster.

Let's start with the biggest tragedy: Tim Curry. A brilliant actor with an illustrious career, Curry is reduced to a cringe-worthy caricature as Herkermer Homolka, a role so cartoonishly absurd it feels like a practical joke. Watching him slum through this embarrassment with a bizarre, unplaceable accent is painful. Curry deserved better than to be forever associated with a film where a talking gorilla named Amy, equipped with a robotic voice glove, is one of the more grounded elements of the story.

And then there's the plot-or rather, the lack of one. The film promises an adventure into the depths of the Congo, filled with danger, mystery, and lost cities, but instead, it delivers endless incoherence. The CGI gorillas are laughably bad, even by 1995 standards, and the climax involving "killer gorillas" is so anticlimactic it feels like a cruel joke. Let's not forget the laser-shooting diamonds-a plot device so ridiculous it belongs in a Sharknado movie, not a pseudo-scientific thriller.

The tone oscillates wildly between attempted seriousness and unintentional comedy. Laura Linney's character is a cold corporate archetype without depth, Ernie Hudson tries his best as a charismatic guide but is bogged down by a nonsensical script, and Dylan Walsh might as well have been replaced by a block of wood.

Any critic who gave this movie a positive review needs to sit down, stare into the void, and reassess every life choice that brought them to that point. Did they see the same movie? Did they fall asleep and dream of a better one? Or were they simply paid off by the filmmakers?

"Congo" is a failure of imagination, execution, and basic dignity. The only mercy is that it eventually ends, though not without taking two agonizing hours of your life you'll never get back. Tim Curry, if you're reading this: we're sorry this happened to you. We truly are.
I'm still waiting for this to end. This movie is not good.

review_title: Entertaining at times, but pretty predictable
review_detailed_main: 1st watched 9/6/1997 - 5 out of 10(Dir-Frank Marshall): Entertaining at times with interesting special effects, but the rest of the time the whole story was pretty predictable and muddled with too many subplots.
Films like Congo make we wonder "Was the director on acid or did he just give no regard for the film's wellbeing?"

Now I'm usually a fan of Tim Curry but quite what he is doing in this rather weak and feeble hybrid of "Tarzan" meets "King Solomon's Mines" is anyone's guess. It's all about the search for a lost expedition that was being led by the son of an American industrialist who was seeking diamonds large enough to power a laser (ostensibly for communications purposes, but who really knows?). Anyway, they disappear so it falls to Curry and Laura Linney's "Dr. Rees" to follow the sagely guidance of the Quatermain-esque "Kelly" (Ernie Hudson) deep into the hostile terrain of the jungle. It's got just about everything required to make it flop, this film. Terrible acting, even worse dialogue - and that's just from the chatty gorilla that all too often saves the day - and some very cheap and cheerful CGI that merely serves to showcase the poor nature of this derivative and rather unremarkable effort. Curry ("Homolka") is just not at the races here and Linney brings very little by way of gravitas to her over-scripted role either. It's rated 12 - but perhaps that's referring to the maximum IQ of anyone whom they are hoping will watch? I wouldn't bother if I were you.

Congo

The reason humans teach gorillas sign language is so they can tell them to release the human child unharmed.

Apparently though, the apt ape in this thriller is only hostile towards female competition.

Primatologist Peter (Dylan Walsh) takes his talking gorilla Amy to Africa after she has a prophetic dream. Along for the ride are an electronics expert (Laura Linney), a philanthropist (Tim Curry) and a local guide (Ernie Hudson), each with their own motive.

Eventually Amy's drawings lead the party to a cache of diamonds that have been protected by a race of vicious grey gorillas for ages, including a powerful blue diamond.

With a laughable premise and even more pathetic special effects behind the man in the monkey suit, this adaptation of the Michael Crichton novel is a low point of 1990s cinema.

Lastly, why teach a primate sign language when it's easier to get them to text? Red Light

Congo is like Michael Christon remade Jurassic Park but with Gorillas being violent and testing the perimeter and killing people and such

Your first hurdle here is that for most of the running time, a gorilla is very clearly being played by a man in a suit. And everyone acts like its a real Gorilla. Then there's the wristband that interprets its gestures into a Stephen Hawking voice and says things a baby would want. Then there's the irresponsible stuff: Gorilla is given a martini, his carer says "she's allowed one." Gorilla is given a cigarette, against her carer's wishes, so he tells her "Don't inhale!" I hope nobody uses this movie as a guide to good Gorilla management because who-ee... Then there's the dialogue. Like, there's a sort of heavy type played by Ernie Hudson, who tells the heroes "I'm your great white hope, I just happen to be black." Just non-stop relentlessly bad writing. Dylan Walsh is a complete absence. He is a massive black hole. He's like that character in The Mighty Boosh where people look at him and don't see a face. I'd say the movie suffers 50% total quality degradation because of this guy. Laura Linney is Laura Linney: you're either in camp Laura Linney or you're most moviegoers and would rather it wasn't Laura Linney. I personally would rather it had been Renee Zellweger or Adrienne Barbeau or some dude. Laura Linney is again more minus value. From my perspective, there's nobody in this who is worth watching.

If this were a movie by the Wayans brothers, I'd probably be giggling. Congo definitely falls into that "so bad its good" category, because its made with slick Hollywood filmmaking, and just happens to feature a string of situations and dialogue so ridiculous they provide a good laugh.

Well, I think I've made my point. This is not good.

review_title: 1995's Congo is Still To This Day One Great Adventure Of a Film Packed With Action, Suspense Moments And At Times a Good Story.
review_detailed_main: When Groups Of Very Different Peoples Are On a Quest To Return a Talking Gorilla To Her Born Place in The Jungle But Along The Entire Group Encounter Dangerous Situations From Jumping Out Of a Cargo Plane With Wearing Parachutes, Meeting Hippo Eating Animals And Finally Meeting The Entire Evil Gorilla Family. Based On The Novel By Michael Crichton The Arthur Of "Jurassic Park" Congo Stars Laura Linney, Dylan Walsh, Ernie Hudson, Jon Don Baker, Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje, Tim Curry And Three Special Appreance By Delroy Lindo, Joe Pantoliano And Bruce Campbell, Jerry Goldsmith Who Did a Very Terrific Great Score And There's Stan Winston Who Created All Of The Gorilla Effects For The Film.

review_title: A movie that will make you laugh. It has some nice scenery and good special effects xcept for the apes lol!

review_detailed_main:
Let's face it; 'Congo' is not a great movie. It is laden with so many flaws and with so many out of place humorist elements - and Tim Curry's comical acting and bad accent - this might be regarded as a comedy, and not the action adventure they were (probably) aiming for. Along with Tim Curry's character, Ernie Hudson was also along for the ride as comic relief.

Yes, there's lots of action and adventure and mystery - in the vein of an Indiana Jones movie or 'Romancing the Stone' or 'Jewel of the Nile'. At times, there's just too much humor - so much so that nothing here can be taken seriously. I'm also not sure I like the idea of a talking gorilla. The visual effects were also mediocre, at best.

Despite all the flaws, 'Congo' is still a rather exciting adventure movie, and I do love adventure movies. I suppose this is the type of movie where you're guaranteed to have a good time if you switch off your brain cells. Don't take it seriously, get the popcorn and sit back and enjoy the ride.

But it is also a heartwarming movie. Especially the connection with the gorilla ''Amy''. I did enjoy watching this. The gorilla Amy made me continue to watch this movie. Amy was so cute, even if you could tell it is fake etc. Overall an entertaining movie.

review_title: Oh my God, I actually watched this!
review_detailed_main:
This is interesting: I was referred to this movie through another movie's reviews. I was quite sure I never watched this one and I wanted to see why this was supposed to be a bad movie. I still remember the stupid commercials on the radio in 1995 which tried to hype this movie as thrilling and exciting.

Now comes the fun part: after reading a few of the reviews, I started to realize that I have actually watched this movie! This is interesting since there is absolutely no connotation in my brain between the title "Congo" and the kind of junk I remember having watched. This ought to mean that the movie was so crappy that I even refused to identify it and just tossed it in my brain's junkyard. I vaguely remember being mildly entertained by the silliness and the cheesy effects of this movie, and the impression of a bunch of mental institution patients trying to re-enact scenes from "Indiana Jones". Because I remember having laughed at all this silliness, I still give it a 3.

My only explanation is that the flashy commercials have caused my brain to imagine a much more exciting movie than it actually was, to such a degree that I refused to believe the thing I watched really was the movie "Congo".

review_title: A movie that delivers on nothing it promises.

review_detailed_main: Congo reminds me very much lake Placid. It serves up a generous portion of belly laughs. And why not. The talent at hand is willing and capably. And the fact that the flick does not take itself too seriously, is a relief for all concerned. Same as in Lake Placid, which is funnier and peppered with more belly laughs than Congo. The movie's got a quick pace that I found to be "just right" with all players having purpose and the main players risking plenty. If, after 30 minutes, you're looking for something more than silly fun, you're a dope. If you're looking for lots of fun, sit back and smile. I loved it.

review_title: A Jungle Adventure Masterpiece From The Beautiful 90's.
review_detailed_main:
I love "Congo" i have ever since i saw it at the cinema on that big screen way back in 1995, "Jurassic park" was a phenomenal hit & these "creature feature" films seemed to have made a comeback, i loved the 90's for movies, this was my era & Congo was a huge film for me!!!

Congo is a fun piece of fantasy escapism & it just brings out the excited kid in me!!! Love Congo.

The Jungle Adventure movie had a bit of a revival during the 90's with Congo & Anaconda, both are Classic's from my era. I loved watching this big fun popcorn blockbuster at the Cinema. The 90's were amazing for movies, especially big budget B-movie type creature features & Congo is one of the best of that time in movie history.

First off i loved the fact that the always underrated Ernie Hudson got a main role as Munroe Kelly & he was so cool as the Hunter/Guide, he made a great leading action hero.

He has a cool & calm charm & is the best character in the movie & that well spoken British accent was genius.

Ernie Hudson has said that this is his best role of his career & i totally agree, it's the best work he's done.

I've liked Ernie Hudson since the Ghostbusters films but of course he was way underused in those but i love his Ghostbusters character Winston Zeddemore.

I would actually go as far as to say that Ernie Hudson is one of the most underrated actors out there.

He's classed as a "Character Actor" meaning he is a bit-part small role acror, but he shouldn't be, given the right film & a chance, he can be great like he is here in "Congo" but he is also great in "The Hand That Rocks The Cradle" a 90s Thriller & the dark 90s vigilante film The Crow & the Classic Ghostbusters 1&2 & a lot of B-movies but He is always good, no matter how small his role my be. Ernie Hudson is also a very Humble guy that just never got the stardom he deserved, he's a million times better than big "A-lister" stars like the Awful "Tom Cult Cruise" but for some reason "Ernie" never got his true big break? But hey I'm a big fan of the man & enjoy checking out anything if i see his name in the cast, i grew up watching him as the cool, everyman Winston Zeddemore in both Ghostbusters films & from there i just like him & his personality on screen & of course Congo came out & showed me how cool he was as a main leading star!!! But of course it didn't last, i treasure his performances especially in as an average joe blue-collar Ghost buster & as a smooth talking African Jungle Guide taking a team deep into the dangerous Congo.

The rest of the cast is very good too especially "Laura Linney" & "Tim Curry" both great actors & give very good performances!!! In fact Congo has one of the best ensemble casts ever with: Bruce Campbell, Laura Linney, Joe Pontaliano, Joe Don Baker, Delroy Lindo, Ernie Hudson, Dylon Walsh, Mary Ellen Trainor, Tim Curry, Grant Heslov & Peter Jason, now that's a Classy Cast right there. Nice seeing all those faces throughout this adventure picture. Congo also has a beautifully touching score by the legendary Jerry Goldsmith. Also lovely scenery & again did i mention an excellent Ernie Hudson. At times Congo feels like very Speilberg & i liked that & it would've considering it's director Frank Marshall has always worked with Speilberg on movies, so some of that magic has rubbed off.

There also such a nice sense of Adventure in the films tone & atmosphere. Truly i think Congo is way underrated & i like it better than Jurassic Park. There's definitely a cosy & comforting feel to this movie now in 2022, probably the Nostalgia i feel for it & remembering watching it on video in the comfort of my living room.

Congo was Directed by Frank Marshall who had Directed another one of my childhood faves, the 1990 Spider-Thriller-Comedy ARACHNOPHOBIA & I've always loved that film, here the Director uses that fun humour-out-of-fear & scary situations for his Congo film, both have that humour & sense of Adventure, Frank Marshall is a very good Director & has obviously learned alot from his friend Spielberg as he's been his producer on alot of his movies. I grew up on Arachnophobia on video from little & then Congo.

Yes the great "Spielberg" was producer this time to his friend "Marshall" on ARACHNOPHOBIA but didn't on Congo?

The mutant gorilla effects still look Amazing, animatronics & men in suits, today it would all be c.g.i so I'm very happy it came out in '95!!!

Congo is a big budget B-movie at heart, it's a fun Jungle Adventure & a Creature Feature with a very good cast of unusual actors for a Jungle movie, but the best role & performance in the movie goes to Ernie Hudson.

One of my personal favourite movies.

A great Jungle Adventure movie, there's heart & a sense of fun, it's pure 90s & should have a "Cult Classic" status!!! It's a childhood fave of mine.

ERNIE HUDSON is Excellent.

I, personally think Congo was an excellent movie. Yes, there was a lot of unbelievable and unrealistic stuff in it, but it was entertaining! Ernie Hudson, Tim Curry And Joe Don Baker All made excellent performances. The music was great as was the scenery. The movie is entertaining and easy to watch. I think every dollar spent making it, showed up in the picture. Congrats to all, especially Marshall & Kennedy! It's east to pick apart a movie but often people don't realize all the work that goes into it. The scenery is especially nice and enjoyable. Ernie Hudson played Monroe Kelly well and believable. Joe Don Baker played a CEO real well too. The Traivs-com headquarters was cool too.

review_title: It is good, but it could've had more action
review_detailed_main:
Come on people¡¡¡ it is not that bad. Well, i think that it doesn't deserve a 4. I see this movie for my first time in my house, when i was 10, and i loved it. I was really impressed with the locations, the tone of the movie, and I have to admit that I jumped from my seat when the president's car explode on the airport scene. Now that i´m 18 I still like it, although i think that needs more action sequences.

The last scene is superb: boiling lava, killer apes, the destruction of the city of zinj, the way all the sets move around, all is very cool.

The bad thing is that the scene ends, and I'm like: "What? that's all" I'm sure that Frank Marshall could've shoot more action sequences. You are staring to get excited and the movie has already ended.

However, I'll give it an 8, because it was cool the first time I saw it.

Congo is a guilty-pleasures movie. If you love watching Ernie Hudson on film, then see this movie. If you love watching bad movies for their HOOTS, see this movie. If you love seeing "the latest in communications technology" (a hand-held superlaser) slice through outrageously campy "white gorillas" see this movie. ...and it even has Tim Curry with a terrible Bulgar accent, and Joe Pantoliano in an unbilled but entertaining part.

Read all the other reviews here first, and if they put you off don't rent the movie, but I skipped reading the book so I don't care if the movie makes mincemeat of it. Nobody thought they were making great art here. I grin all the way through whenever I watch it.

Not a serious ounce in this film. From over the top performances through hilarious accents and humourous banter, this film is a charming cheese-fest.

It is almost as if the initial intention was to make a typically dry Crichton film, but then the good nature of those involved took over and they had a lot more fun. Taking it seriously is clearly a bad idea. I mean - the first actor you see is Bruce Campbell for goodness sake!

review_title: At only a mere 5 points, this is a sadly under-rated action film.

review_detailed_main:
*SPOILERS* Trying to latch onto the blockbuster Jurassic Park franchise, Congo was met with mixed reactions at the summer box office but still managed to be a minor hit. Opening with a sexy Bruce Campbell as its opening kill. We fast forward to ex girlfriend Laura Linney (Exorcism of Emily Rose) going to the Congo to save him. Along with Ernie Hudson (Ghostbusters) donning a cool accent, Tim Curry (Rocky Horror Picture Show) also donning a cool accent, cutie Dylan Walsh (Nip/Tuck) and a friendly talking gorilla named Amy amongst others. The movie is goofy and fun and at times it feels like it's a stage production because of some questionable FX. That being said faults aside of which there are quite a bit from goofy performances to underdeveloped characters and goofy direction to name a few. The movie still works. Its dumb but perfectly entertaining.

4/5

Future advise and outrage adventure! Through the day is nothing like the movies on gorillas today :) "2021 here!"

#EpicScene.

Herkermer Homolka (Tim Curry) has been looking for the Lost City of Zinj. He is contemplating picking up a few souvenirs when he finds them. Seems that the only one that has been there is Amy (Misty Rosas). However, Amy needs to go home. Her buddy and mentor are economically tapped out. So, they all team up with Dr. Karen Ross (Laura Linney) who just happens to be going in that direction and can afford the travel arrangements. While Karen thinks she is going to save fellow explorers, her boss also has a nefarious plan.

Will Amy go home?

Will Karen find her friend "alive"?

Does the boss's plan come to fruition?

Will Herkermer Homolka get his trinkets or his fingers Zinj'd?

What secret does the lost city hold?

Let's face it Tim Curry makes the movie. Not only does he excel in his character but allows others to play off him. Otherwise, this would just be a run-of-the-mill misadventure film. Great accent.

Don't understand the haters as this is a great bit of fun and spot on for a lazy Sunday afternoon.

Get some snacks and a drink and sit back and enjoy.

Won't inspire or shake your soul but it's a great adventure flick with some serious primates who just want to be left alone.

Watching again now and can't wait.

I'm not going to spoil anything so you can read the synopsis about the plot.

So i was 20 years old when I first saw this movie. The public Internet was like 5 years old. I was young and impressionable. While the science of the movie is somewhat implausible, it still has a lighthearted story.

Great VFX for its time. There are a few memorable moments of humor. Tim Curry is hilarious as Mr. Homolka, and the cake scene with Captain Wanta is one of the funniest scenes that has stuck with me all my life.

The gorilla is well acted, and is adorable. Linney and Walsh do their job well as leads. Hudson, Heslow and a few others do their job as well.

This is one of the gems from the 90s that you really want to watch, if you can keep away from Facebook, Instagram, TikTok or whatever.

review_title: Bad Acting, Silly Safari-Adventure, Good Time
review_detailed_main:
Okay, so maybe this shouldn't have received a 10, it isn't Casablanca, or even an Indiana Jones caliber movie. But, I do like this movie quite a lot and feel more people should give it a chance.

I think Congo failed because of marketing, first and foremost. This got the summer blockbuster treatment, and unfortunately, generated an audience that didn't suit the film.

On the one level this film completely works as a children's adventure movie, and on the other appeals to film-buff looking for some good fun.

Let's get this out of the way. The acting is terrible. I mean really, really poor. There's a sign language-using monkey-suited midget with accompanying computerized voice synthesizer. And to top it all off there is Tim Curry.

When I think of Congo I think of one character, Herkermer Homolka, played by Tim Curry. Even with thousands of movies under my belt, I still can't be sure if Curry turned-in one of the very worst performances of all-time, or whether he was just hamming it up. Regardless of why, Herkermer Homolka is one of the most enjoyable Hollywood characters ever created. Is it the terrible accent? Is it the ridiculously, one dimensional stereotype of the shyster? I can't say. But I can tell you that the character has left me in tears laughing on more than one occasion.

I don't really remember a ton of the plot. They're trying to take the talking Gorilla back to Africa or something, and there's a diamond Volcano involved. You also have a ultra powerful mega-corporation paying for the adventure.

I should also note that this movie has a very entertaining performance turned in by Ernie Hudson as the pragmatic liaison between the civilized west and savage Africans (passing bribes and such).

Finally, one thing to watch out for, are the completely racist stereotypes of the Africans. They are portrayed as either corrupt, cowardly, superstitious, or all three. Watching this movie is much like watching an old Tarzan flick. If you, yourself, aren't racist I think you'll just sort of shake your head at the stupidity of it all and get a chuckle thinking about how angry the actors having to play the "savages" must have been.

So, this is a throw-back movie. It isn't good acting, the plot is contrived and silly, the entire narrative seems to use stereotyped caricatures, and there's a guy in a gorilla suit. You can see why some people hate this movie.

On the other hand, if you appreciate a good Hollywood safari-adventure flick, this one doesn't disappoint. In fact, it entertains.
Not sure why the rating on this is so low. Easy to watch with likable characters that just flow.

Ok ok, so this isn't the most plausible story every written, but there are a lot more implausible ones out there with better ratings! This movie is a lot of fun, it is a decent and fun if nothing else adaptation of the book, and as far as movies go about the search for King Solomon's mines go, it's heads and shoulders above all the others. As one of my friends pointed out to me they didn't really take full advantage of Amy the gorrilla. If they gave her some one liners it would have been much better. IE:The scene where they finally discover the lost city, and first have a shot of the city then they camera zooms on Amy's face...this would be a perfect time to have her say and sign something like "We meet again City of Zinj!" or how about at the end when they are running away from the lava and Peter the scientist almost falls into the lava. When Amy turns around and sees it they should have her sign "Peeeeeetttteeeeerrrrrrr!!!!" and have her hold the sign for a moment or two. It would have been what is known back east as "comedic gold", or at least "Comedic diamonds" (pun intended). Anyway this movie is fun, I gave it an 8 to boost it's score but in reality it's probably around a 6-7, still way better then a 4 point something.

review_title: DIAMONDS FOR THE CAPITALISTS. DEATH FOR THE GORILLAS!
review_detailed_main:
This is the greatest film. A cinematic treasure for all ages. Sure, I have a few nagging complaints:

1. The story line makes little or no sense.

2. The apes' costumes look fake.

3. The actors in the film are 3rd rate at best.

But don't let this small list of complaints take away from the fact that this film is truly brilliant. I was literally on my knees praying to God, for the safe return of the hero during the final act. Truly gripping!

Several people have shared with me that they loved this film so much, they named their first child, "cannibal", after the evil gray gorillas who ate Charlie's face in act 1. To be honest, I'm an animal lover who does not wish to see harm come to our gorilla friends. Having said that, when the evil grey gorillas attempted to protect their blue diamonds from the evil Capitalists, I celebrated when the gorillas were caught in a hail of machine gun fire.

The Capitalists simply wanted access to the horde of blue diamonds and the evil grey gorillas did everything they could to stop them. In the end, the gorillas lost and greed won. The natural order of things was restored.

Honestly, this is a wonderful movie that the whole family can learn to enjoy. In fact, I would encourage schools to show this film in Animal Studies 101. As the lessons learned in this film are timeless.

The main takeaway is..blue diamonds are a dead gorillas best friend.
